folder: Central Park., Manhattan, NY
text:
TEN THOUSAND NEW YORK SCHOOLBOYS DRILLING IN CENTRAL PARK.
This is a great army of schoolboys from all boroughs of the big city, attired in white shirtwaists & dark knickerbockers, gave an exhibition drill in the physical exercises in the city's largest park last month before a distinguished company of invited guests, relatives & friends.  The purpose of this impressive demonstration, which was held under the auspices of the Public Schools Athletic League, was to show the results of physical and hygienic training in the schools.  Colonel Roosevelt, who was one of the spectators, spoke of the work of the League as a great force for good not only in the city but in the nation.

Dated:  June 10, 1913.  American Press Ass'n
Neg # 2333
title: Manhattan: Central Park.

folder: Central Park entrance at Columbus Circle., Manhattan, NY
text:
Central Park: Southwestern entrance (originally called Merchant's Gate), at Columbus Circle, with the ball ground and Green in the center background. The monument at the entrance of the Park was erected to commemorate the sailors who were lost when the battleship Maine was blown up -- the incident which led to the Spanish-American War. The Columbus statue, by Russo, stands on the tall pedestal in the middle of the Circle, in the left foreground. Along the horizon may be seen the buildings on Fifth Avenue and the East Side.

About 1922.

Ewing Galloway.
title: Manhattan: Central Park entrance at Columbus Circle.

folder: Central Park & Drives, Manhattan, NY
text:
(1) Central Park: The West Drive, Central Park West, from 71st to 73rd Streets, in the background. The apartment buildings shown are the old Majestic and the Dakota, on either side of 72nd Street.

Notice the tree full of pigeons. Autumn, 1923.

P.L. Sperr.

(2) The West Drive, part of the exit branch for southbound traffic leaving the park at 72nd Street. In the background is Central Park West from 73rd to 72nd Streets, inclusive. May 17, 1933.

P.L. Sperr.

(3) The West Drive, near the Lake, showing Central Park West from 76th to 71st Streets. The buildings shown, from right to left, are the Church of the Divine Paternity (Universalist), the Kenilworth apartment house, the new San Remo, the Langham, the Dakota (the oldest in the picture), and the new Majestic. May 17, 1933.

P.L. Sperr.
Negative #1775
title: Manhattan: Central Park - Drives

folder: Central Park & [View of the Arsenal Building.], Manhattan, NY
text:
Central Park: A set of 4 views of the Arsenal under reconstruction, photographed in a northeastward direction from in the Park, showing the rear of same with the menagerie to the south (frame structures on the right). Across the background are buildings on the east side of Fifth Ave. at about 64th Street. The corner stone of this structure was laid on July 4, 1847. Later it became the headquarters of the Park Police; who still occupy same today (1938).

January 1924.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
title: Manhattan: Central Park - [View of the Arsenal Building.]

folder: Central Park & [View of the Arsenal Building.], Manhattan, NY
text:
Central Park: A set of 5 views of the Arsenal under reconstruction as viewed westward (north and southward) from Fifth Ave. (foreground) at East 64th Street. This structure was erected in 1848 at a cost of $30,000 (as given in 1853). The City of New York purchased same in 1856 from the State for a sum of $275,000. The first floor was used for Administrative offices while the 2nd and 3rd were occupied by the Museum, which later became the American Museum of Natural History. The Meteorological Observatory for years occupied a large upper room.

January 1924.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
title: Manhattan: Central Park - [View of the Arsenal Building.]

The first floor was used for Administrative offices while the 2nd and 3rd were occupied by the Museum, which later became the American Museum of Natural History. The Meteorological Observatory for years occupied a large upper room.

January 1924.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
title: Manhattan: Central Park - [View of the Arsenal Building.]

folder: Central Park & [View of the Arsenal Building.], Manhattan, NY
text:
Central Park: A set of 5 views of the Arsenal under reconstruction as viewed westward (north and southward) from Fifth Ave. (foreground) at East 64th Street. This structure was erected in 1848 at a cost of $30,000 (as given in 1853). The City of New York purchased same in 1856 from the State for a sum of $275,000. The first floor was used for Administrative offices while the 2nd and 3rd were occupied by the Museum, which later became the American Museum of Natural History. The Meteorological Observatory for years occupied a large upper room.

January 1924.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
title: Manhattan: Central Park - [View of the Arsenal Building.]

folder: Central Park & [Aerial view.], Manhattan, NY
text:
IDENTIFICATION: Central Park
DATE: 1927?
PHOTOGRAPHER: Fairchild Aerial Surveys, Inc.
270 W. 38, NYC
REPRODUCTION RIGHTS: Held by Photographer

title: Manhattan: Central Park - [Aerial view.]

folder: Central Park & Pathways. [Ritz Tower ; Sherry-Netherland Hotel]., Manhattan, NY
text:
Central Park, Pathways: A set of 2 views photographed in a southeast-ward direction to show prominently Ritz Tower, the Sherry Netherland Hotel and the Squibb Building.

October 11, 1927.
View 2:-September 14, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Central Park - Pathways. [Ritz Tower ; Sherry-Netherland Hotel].

folder: Central Park & Pathways. [Ritz Tower ; Sherry-Netherland Hotel]., Manhattan, NY
text:

October 11, 1927.
View 2:-September 14, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Central Park - Pathways. [Ritz Tower ; Sherry-Netherland Hotel].

folder: Central Park & The Drive., Manhattan, NY
text:
Central Park: The Drive, connecting link between Sixth and Seventh Avenues, showing 59th Street, west from and including Seventh Avenue. The Manufacturers' Trust Building in the background is at 307 West 59th Street, adjoining Columbus Circle; it used to be the Gotham National Bank Building. The branch to the left leads to the Sixth Avenue entrance; and the branch in the lower right hand side of the picture leads north to the Mall, where it joins the driveway from the Fifth Avenue entrance and forms the East Drive. Since the date of this picture that branch has been reserved for one-way traffic, going north; and the connecting link shown here is used by eastbound cars exclusively, whether bound for Sixth Avenue or for the East Drive. May 25, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Central Park - The Drive.

folder: Central Park entrance at Columbus Circle., Manhattan, NY
text:
Central Park: The southwestern entrance at Columbus Circle and showing the Maine Monument there. On the right appears buildings on the south side of Central Park South (West 59th Street); the southern confine of this central garden area.

About 1928.

Ewing Galloway.
title: Manhattan: Central Park entrance at Columbus Circle.

folder: Central Park & Pathways., Manhattan, NY
text:
Central Park: Pathways and greensward on the eastern side, showing Fifth Avenue south from about 99th Street.
May 15, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Central Park - Pathways.

folder: Central Park & Gardens -The Shakespeare Garden., Manhattan, NY
text:
Central Park, Gardens: The Shakespeare Garden, on the western side of the Park near 81st Street. Central Park West, from 81st to 76th Streets, is in the background.
February 2, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Central Park - Gardens -The Shakespeare Garden.

folder: Central Park & Playgrounds [Ball ground and athletic fields and the Green.], Manhattan, NY
text:
Central Park: Ball Ground and athletic field, and the Green, in the southwestern corner of the Park, with Columbus Circle and Eighth Avenue in the foreground. In the upper left hand corner Central Park West runs off the picture about 69th Street; and in the upper right hand corner may be seen the southern end of the Mall. The old sheepfold, between the West Drive and the 66th Street gate, will be rebuilt in 1934 as an outdoor restaurant, The Tavern on the Green.
In this aerial view the driveways, bridle path, and pedestrian pathways stand out very clearly.

About 1929.

Ewing Galloway.
title: Manhattan: Central Park - Playgrounds [Ball ground and athletic fields and the Green.]

folder: Central Park., Manhattan, NY
text:
Central Park: Aerial View from Hotel Sherry-Netherland at the southeastern corner of the Park, showing the old Arsenal and the Zoo, which is to be rebuilt in 1934, in the right foreground. To the left may be seen the Green, or south meadow, and behind it Central Park West at 72nd Street. The Mall is in the center of the picture, just south of the Lake. On the east side, at Fifth Avenue and 80th Street, are the buildings of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and to the left of them the old Lower Reservoir, rectangular in shape, which at the time of this picture is shortly to go into disuse, with the view of later making it into a garden. The North Reservoir is the large body of water above it.
Central Park West, from 72nd to 96th Streets, is shown at the left.
Summer, 1930.

Ewing Galloway.

Negative photograph available in 444 G. Neg. No. 144
title: Manhattan: Central Park.

folder: Central Park & Playgrounds [field on the North Meadow.], Manhattan, NY
text:
PLAYGROUNDS:
Central Park: Athletic Field in North Meadow, Pool and Harlem Heights in the foreground; the view is southeast from Central Park West, showing Fifth Avenue buildings from 95th Street south to the Plaza. The upper reservoir is seen in the center background.
Wurts Brothers                          May 21, 1930
title: Manhattan: Central Park - Playgrounds [field on the North Meadow.]

folder: Central Park & The Sailboat Pool, Manhattan, NY
text:
(1) Central Park: The Sailboat Pool as viewed northward and showing also the Fifth Ave. building outline. Prominent on the right is the Carlyle.

About 1930.


(2) A more inclusive view.

May 2, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Central Park - The Sailboat Pool

folder: Central Park & The Sailboat Pool, Manhattan, NY

folder: Central Park & Pathways [and woods near Harlem Heights]., Manhattan, NY
text:
Central Park: Pathways and Woods, Harlem Heights, a view west from Fifth Avenue at 100th Street, showing Morningside Heights in the background.
The Cathedral of St. John the Divine, at 112th Street, is approximately in the center background. To the right of it is the tower of the new Riverside Baptist Church.
In the Park, the East Drive may be seen in the center of the picture. The Loch is hidden by the trees west of the Drive.
September 8, 1931.

Wurts Brothers.
title: Manhattan: Central Park - Pathways [and woods near Harlem Heights].

folder: Central Park & Playgrounds [between North Meadow and Upper Reservoir.], Manhattan, NY
text:
Central Park: Playgrounds, in the North Meadow, and tennis courts between the North Meadow and the Upper Reservoir. The view is northeast towards upper Fifth Avenue. The driveway in the foreground is the West Drive. A gate house on the northern side of the Upper Reservoir may be seen at the extreme right.
May 10, 1931.

Wurts Brothers.
title: Manhattan: Central Park - Playgrounds [between North Meadow and Upper Reservoir.]

folder: Central Park & Aerial view from Radio City., Manhattan, NY
text:
Central Park: Aerial View from Radio City (Sixth Avenue and 51st Street), showing the Park and the Fifth Avenue side. In the center foreground may be seen the Pond, north of it the Mall, then the Lake, of which the eastern bay is at the northern end of the Mall and the main body on the west side of the Park, about 70th to 80th Streets. The bare spot further north is the site of the old reservoir; above it may be seen the north reservoir, still in use. The buildings of the Metropolitan Museum of Art may be seen on the Fifth Avenue side at 81st Street.

August 9, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

The same, another view. In the southwestern quarter of the Park may be seen a ball ground, and north of it the Meadow or Green. The 72nd Street cross drive separates the Green and the Lake.

August 9, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

The same, also showing the West Side of town and the Hudson River. The Riverside Church, at 122nd Street, and the George Washington Bridge, at 181st Street, stand out very clearly.

August 9, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Central Park - Aerial view from Radio City.

Entrance Driveway for West Drive traffic entering Central Park at the West 79th Street entrance (the Old Hunters' Gate). The older part of the Natural History Museum, near 77th Street, is shown in the background.

May 17, 1933.

P.L. Sperr.

text:
Central Park: The Southwestern Entrance, originally known as the Merchants' Gate, at Columbus Circle, showing the monument erected to the sailors lost in the sinking of the Maine (the incident that precipitated the Spanish-American War).
May 21, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Central Park entrance at Columbus Circle.

May 15, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

folder: Central Park & Sailboat pond., Manhattan, NY
text:
Central Park: Sailboat Pool, with the Park and Fifth Avenue houses around 80th Street in the background.
May 17, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

The same, another view; showing the large model and a tiny model sailboat on their way towards the western edge of the pool, where they will meet. (See the last of this series, the view showing no Fifth Avenue houses at all).
May 17, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

The same from the southern edge. This pool is also known as Conservatory Lake.
May 2, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Central Park - Sailboat pond.

folder: Central Park & Sailboat pond., Manhattan, NY
text:
Central Park: The Sailboat Pool, near Fifth Avenue and 75th Street, the western edge of the pool; the view is north. Two models of racing yachts, a big one and a small one, have crossed the pool from different directions and are coming together at the finish. Their owners are waiting for them.
May 17, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Central Park - Sailboat pond.

folder: Central Park & Transverse roads [Transverse Road No.1]., Manhattan, NY
text:
Central Park: Transverse Road No. 1, near the entrance at Fifth Avenue and 65th Street. The western end of the road is at 66th Street. The twin towers on the horizon, in the right background, belong to the El Dorado apartment building on Central Park West, 90th to 91st Streets.

May 21, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Central Park - Transverse roads [Transverse Road No.1].

folder: Central Park & [General view] from Rockefeller Center, Radio City., Manhattan, NY
text:
Central Park, as seen from Rockefeller Center, (Radio City). Also shown is a general view of midtown Manhattan between the Hudson (left) and East (right) Rivers. Silhouetted against the Park is the West 59th skyline, consisting of the Essex House, Barbizon Plaza, N. Y. Athletic Club and the Plaza Hotel buildings.

About 1934.

Rockefeller Center
Hamilton Wright
title: Manhattan: Central Park - [General view] from Rockefeller Center, Radio City.

folder: Central Park & Casino., Manhattan, NY
text:
Central Park: Workmen demolishing the Casino in accordance with Mayor LaGuardia and Park Commissioner Moses plan to return all public parks to the general public. During Mayor Walkers incumbency this structure was leased to a private restaurant corporation which through its extreme prices created an exclusive atmosphere.

May 12, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Central Park - Casino.

folder: Central Park & Casino., Manhattan, NY
text:
Central Park: Workmen demolishing the Casino in accordance with Mayor LaGuardia and Park Commissioner Moses plan to return all public parks to the general public. During Mayor Walkers incumbency this structure was leased to a private restaurant corporation which through its extreme prices created an exclusive atmosphere.

May 12, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Central Park - Casino.

folder: Central Park & The Menagerie., Manhattan, NY
text:
Central Park, as seen from the Hotel Pierre (Fifth Ave., at East 61st Street), and showing a view northwesterly. prominently shown in the foreground, (southeastern corner of the Park) is the newly remodeled Zoo. The labor and funds being supplied by the United States Government and the W.P.A. The former presidential aspirant, Alfred E. Smith, is the honorary headkeeper.

1936.

W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Writers Project.
title: Manhattan: Central Park - The Menagerie.

folder: Central Park & Miscellaneous [Boat lake also known as the Pond]., Manhattan, NY
text:
Central Park: A photographer snaps the "wild Life" in the southeastern corner of the Park. The body of water in the background in the Boat Lake, also known as The Pond.

Gift of Dr. Michael Wishengrad F.R.P.S.

About 1936.
title: Manhattan: Central Park - Miscellaneous [Boat lake also known as the Pond].

folder: Central Park & Miscellaneous [clouds formation]., Manhattan, NY
text:
Central Park; Miscellaneous; Cloud formations as seen from the Park.
About 1936.
Gift of Dr. Michael Wishengrad F.Rqp.S.
title: Manhattan: Central Park - Miscellaneous [clouds formation].

folder: Central Park & The Seal Pool., Manhattan, NY
text:
Central Park: The Seal Pool, located in the center of the newly rebuilt Central Park Zoo. Note the animal houses in the background.

About 1936.

Gift of Dr. Michael Wishengrad F.R.P.S.
title: Manhattan: Central Park - The Seal Pool.

folder: Central Park & Transverse roads [Transverse road No. 1]., Manhattan, NY
text:
Central Park: Transverse Road No. 1, showing the W.P.A. constructing a sewer. This road connects East 65th Street at Fifth Ave. with West 68th Street, at Central Park West. October 8, 1936.

W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Art Project.
title: Manhattan: Central Park - Transverse roads [Transverse road No. 1].

About 1936.

folder: Central Park & The Seal Pool., Manhattan, NY
text:
Central Park's new zoo provides modern housing for its wide variety of animals.
Sept. 1936
title: Manhattan: Central Park - The Seal Pool.

folder: Central Park & The Seal Pool., Manhattan, NY

May 1937.

Gift of Geo. D. Chinn.

(2) The elephant enjoying the attention of Sunday visitors. The buildings housing same have recently been reconstructed under the aid of the U. S. Government.

May 1937.

Gift of Geo. D. Chinn.

folder: Central Park & [Arsenal Building on 5th Avenue.], Manhattan, NY
text:
Arsenal Building in Central Park, on Fifth Avenue, is the headquarters of the Park Police where two or three hundred men are stationed. They are on independent body under the control of the Park Commissioners.

No Record of Photographers

folder: Central Park entrance., Manhattan, NY
text:
Central Park Entrance: The Equestrian Statue of General William Tecumseh Sherman. The group, consisting of the equestrian figure and a female figure on a pedestal decorated with six applied wreaths (three on each side)is located at Grand Army Plaza in Manhattan at 59th Street and 5th Avenue, at the entrance to Central Park.

Dr. Michael Wishengrad.
title: Manhattan: Central Park entrance.

folder: Central Park & [Wading pool.], Manhattan, NY
text:
Central Park.
"The Hotter It Is the Better They Like It!" Let that old thermometer roar. These youngsters didn't care. They had one glorious time of it in wading pool at Central Park yesterday.
"P & A Photo"
From Review of Reviews Corp.
